p: Kulthe et al. and Tahera et al. [ 46, 47] reported the antibacterial activity of Calpurnia leaf extracts against nine enteric pathogens tested including E. coli O157 H:7, S. typhi, and other species. Likewise, Romha et al. and Kalayou et al. [ 48, 49] reported the antibacterial activity of Calpurnia leaf extracts against E. coli, S. typhi, S. pyogenes, and S. aureus clinical isolates. C. jejuni shows MIC on the leaf, bark, and root, while L. monocytogenes shows on leaf (3.125 mg/ml) ethanol extracts of C. aurea which is in line with the finding of Elisha et al. [ 14]. As commonly known, the Gram-negative bacteria are more resistant than the Gram-positive ones [ 9]; however, the current study showed that 3 of the Gram-negative bacteria used in this study were sensitive to this extract even at a high MIC of 3.125 mg/ml. Among the positive controls, antibiotic treatment with penicillin showed resistance to E. coli O157 H:7 and S. aureus at 0.1 and 0.2 mg/ml. This suggests that the C. aurea ethanol extract compound might be used instead of penicillin treatment of these disease-causing pathogens.
